title: Man who 'killed two in Halle synagogue shooting' wanted to commit 'massacre'
text:

The chief suspect in the German synagogue attack yesterday which left two people dead wanted 'to carry our a massacre', according to the country's federal prosecutor.

He also wanted to inspire others to carry out similar attacks.

Peter Frank said: "What we experienced yesterday was terrorism.

"According to our findings, the suspect Stephan B. aimed to carry out a massacre."

He said the suspect seemed to have built several of his own weapons and explosives were found in his car.

(Image: dpa/AFP via Getty Images)

(Image: ATV-Studio Halle/AFP via Getty I)

The gunman, who tried to force his way into a synagogue in the town of Halle on Wednesday before killing two people, broadcast his rampage on the Twitch platform.

After trying to blast into the Halle synagogue, the lone suspect killed a woman outside and a man in a nearby kebab shop.

The attack could have had more victims if his homemade firearms had not malfunctioned, footage broadcast on the livestreaming platform suggests.

(Image: REUTERS)

(Image: dpa/AFP via Getty Images)

The footage shows the suspect becoming increasingly frustrated as his homemade weapons repeatedly malfunction. In at least three instances the video shows the suspect pointing a gun directly at a victim only for the weapon to jam.

Calling himself a “loser”, at one point he says: “I have certainly managed to prove how absurd improvised weapons are.”

After attacks on both a synagogue and a kebab shop, according to the livestreamed footage, the gunman said: “Sorry, guys, the ****ing Luty is s**t!”

Most Jewish institutions in Germany's large cities have a near-permanent police guard due to occasional anti-Semitic

attacks by both far-right activists and Islamist militants.

(Image: FILIP SINGER/EPA-EFE/REX)

Police said they had detained one person, identified by the magazines Spiegel and Focus Online as a 27-year-old German, Stephan B. His full name cannot be published under German privacy laws.

Several German media outlets said he acted alone although police have not confirmed this.
description: The federal prosecutor in Germany said that the country 'experienced terrorism' on Wednesday
